title: Technical Debt vs Feature Request
description: The PM has prioritized a new feature that users are requesting. However, you've identified critical technical debt that's causing 20% of user bugs. The refactor would take 2 weeks, same as the feature. The PM is pushing for the feature to ship this sprint.

choices.text: Advocate strongly for doing the refactor first, using data on bugs and velocity to explain the long-term impact of technical debt.
Ship the feature now but clearly document the technical debt as a blocker for the next sprint.
Work extra hours to try to do both this sprint, taking on the extra load yourself.

title: Scope Creep Mid-Sprint
description: You're midway through a sprint when the founder asks you to add 'one small feature' to the current release. It's not smallâ€”it would require rearchitecting part of your solution. The team is already stretched.

choices.text: Push back firmly and explain the engineering implications
Accept the request but cut corners to make it work
Propose a minimal version that fits within the current architecture and has a clear upgrade path later.

title: Junior Engineer Struggling
description: A junior engineer is blocked on a critical task and deadlines are tight.

choices.text: Reassign the task to yourself to ensure it's done on time.
Pair program with them to help unblock and teach.
Give them a quick hint and let them figure it out.

title: Unrealistic Deadline
description: The founder promises a client feature in two weeks. You know it needs four. Do you:

choices.text: Say nothing and work extra hours to meet the deadline.
Push back immediately, explaining the risks of rushing.
Negotiate a scope reduction to meet the deadline.

title: Surprise Customer Calls
description: The founder messages: 'Can you jump on 3 customer calls today? We need someone technical.' You weren't hired for sales, but the calls are happening soon and the stakes are high.

choices.text: Refuse the calls and offer an alternative: write a technical FAQ / escalation guide, and only join if there's a deep technical escalation.
Accept immediately with no questions and run the calls as requested.
Do it, but make it clear it's temporary and propose a proper rotation + escalation path going forward.

title: Finished Sprint Work Early
description: You finished all your sprint tickets in half the estimated time. There are still several days left in the sprint, and no one has noticed yet.

choices.text: Tell the team you're free and ask for more work or offer to help someone who's blocked.
Keep quiet and use the time for personal life or low-key learning.
Use the time to find something meaningful to improve (tests, CI, monitoring), bring data, and propose it ASAP.

title: Hard Feature, Deadline Slipping
description: You're stuck on a hard part of a feature and you're pretty sure you won't meet the deadline unless something changes.

choices.text: Say nothing for now and try to figure it out solo; only explain the miss after it's clearly impossible.
Inform the founder ASAP with the reason and present options (reduce scope, move deadline, or get help).
Ask a teammate to pair and research known issues (docs, GitHub issues, forums), then report back with what you found.
